body_html:
Sometimes mkl caps the number of threads below your system's max. See mkl's cap via mkl.get_max_threads(). To increase the cap to your actual max, use export MKL_DYNAMIC=FALSE in bash before running Python. Find your actual max via echo $(nproc) in bash.

Intel's documentation:
https://software.intel.com/en-us/mkl-linux-developer-guide-mkl-dynamic

I came across this solution in this issue:
ContinuumIO/mkl-service#2

Intel's documentation:

I came across this solution in this issue:
ContinuumIO/mkl-service#2
body:
Sometimes mkl caps the number of threads below your system's max. See mkl's cap via `mkl.get_max_threads()`. To increase the cap to your actual max, use `export MKL_DYNAMIC=FALSE` in bash before running Python. Find your actual max via `echo $(nproc)` in bash.

Intel's documentation:
https://software.intel.com/en-us/mkl-linux-developer-guide-mkl-dynamic

I came across this solution in this issue:
https://github.com/ContinuumIO/mkl-service/issues/2
